STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 14, 2023
Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Guiding Harbor
525 E Huron River Dr.
Belleville MI, 48111-3665
Re: License #: CB820201144
Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
5/23/2023. A Exit conference was held with you on 6/1/2023. Due to the violations of
applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201144
Licensee Group Organization: Girlstown Foundation
Licensee Designee: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Name of Agency: GUIDING HARBOR
Agency Address: 525 E HURON RIVER DR
BELLEVILLE, MI 48111-3665
Agency Telephone #: 7346977242
Original Issuance Date: 05/20/1989
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 5/15/2023-5/23/2023
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 9 3
Homes pending licensure 11 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 6 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 1 1
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 2 2
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
parental home, relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 36 6
Children discharged from care during this period 14 4
Youth in independent living placement 2 2
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 2 2
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 3 3
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection 0 0
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 4 3
Open child adoption cases 18 4
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 6 5
Less than a year 8 8
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 1
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 3
Administrative Staff 2
2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 7 3
Unlicensed relative homes 22 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 4
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the investigation shall not exceed
90 calendar days without approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
In one of two special evaluations reviewed the record did not show documentation
of a 45-day letter; nor written approval from the chief administrator or his or her
designee for this special evaluation which was extended much longer than 90
calendar days.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
One of two special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that the
written report was completed within 15 days of the 1/13/2023 conclusion to the
foster parent.
2

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following shall be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care
up to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
and (b) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after
placement.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's medical
examination due by 5/7/2022 was completed 47 days late on 6/16/2022.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 14-month medical
examination, due by April 2023, was not documented.
3

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
Two of three initial service plans reviewed were completed four and eight days late
respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Eight of 28 updated service plans (USP) reviewed (related to four open foster child
records and two open independent living youth records) were late:
Foster child records:
• One foster child’s 10/5/2022-1/2/2023 USP was completed two days late on
1/4/2023. This child’s 1/3/2023-4/2/2023 USP was completed one day late on
4/3/2023.
• A second foster child’s 7/2/2022-9/29/2022 USP was completed one day late
on 9/30/2023. This child’s12/29/2022-3/28/2023 USP was completed 29 days
late on 4/26/2023.
• A third foster child’s 5/24/2022-8/21/2022 USP was completed four days late
on 8/25/2022.
• A fourth foster child’s 12/2/2022-3/1/2023 USP was completed 15 days late
on 3/16/2023.
Independent living youth records:
• One youth’s 10/25/2022-1/22/2023 USP was completed four days late on
1/26/2023. This youth’s 1/23/2023-4/22/2023 USP was completed six days
late on 4/28/2023.
• A second youth’s 2/12/2023-5/12/2023 USP was completed five days late on
5/17/2023.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
4

CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the
foster parent.
One of three initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of the
behavior management plan to be used by the caregiver with the foster child.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any
changes made since the previous plan and which is to be
used by the foster parents.
Three of 28 updated services plans reviewed (related to one foster child’s record),
did not show documentation of the behavior management plan to be used by the
caregiver with the foster child.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in independent
living.
Two of two independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
the youth was provided a copy of the program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
5

Two of two independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
that a copy of the policy and procedures were provided to the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(e) An evaluation of a youth’s need for supervision
and a plan for providing the level of supervision
determined necessary.
Two of two independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of an evaluation of the youth's need for supervision and a plan for providing such.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
Two of two open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One youth’s record did not show documentation of initial financial support to
meet the youth needs.
• A second youth’s record showed documentation that initial financial support
to meet the youth’s needs was due by 2/4/2023 and not completed until
3/17/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of two independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of an updated quarterly independent living contract, due by April 2023.
6

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all of the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care
and the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
One of two closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) and (d) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of three adoptive evaluation records reviewed did not show documentation that
the adoptive evaluation was completed within 90 days of the family's 6/17/2022
application date.
Repeat Violation -Renewal 2022
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
Three of three adoptive evaluation records reviewed did not show documentation
that the family's respective 3130 adoption assessment and or DHS-612 adoptive
assessment was provided the adoptive family upon its completion.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
MCL 722. 120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of confidential
records; child information cards to be provided to
7

department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and
care and shall report to the department, when
requested, the facts the department requires with
reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this
subsection and subsection (4), records regarding
children and facts compiled about children and their
parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by
the childcare organization, the department, and any
other entity in possession of the information.
Records that are confidential under this section are
available to both of the following:
In one of two special evaluations reviewed, the record showed documentation of
children protective service (CPS) involvement and CPS language.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment and Addendum.
Child Adoption Assessment Timeframes:
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
Child adoption assessment addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not been
placed for adoption.
Three of four open child adoption records reviewed (related to five Child Adoption
Assessments {CAA} reviewed, did not show compliance:
• One child’s CAA due by 8/12/2022 was completed timely by the worker on
6/12/2022, but not approved by the supervisor until 5/15/2023.
• A second child’s CAA was due by 9/4/2022 and not completed until
11/21/2022.
• A third child’s CAA dated 12/1/2022 was completed late, per the 8/26/2022
case assignment date.
8

In one of four open child adoption records reviewed, the child’s CAA addendum due
by February 2023 was not documented.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022- Interim 2021.
ADM 330 Quarterly Progress Report.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be
completed each quarter.
Four of four open child adoption records reviewed (related to 14 quarterly progress
reports) did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of a September 2022,
December 2022 or March 2023 quarterly progress report.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of a July 2022, October
2022, January 2023 or April 2023 quarterly progress report.
• A third child’s record showed the child 8/26/2022-11/24/2022 quarterly
progress report was completed late on 12/1/2022. The February 2023
quarterly progress report for this child was not documented.
• A fourth child’s records showed the child’s 7/21/2022-10/19/2022 quarterly
progress report was completed late on 11/29/2022. This child’s 10/20/2022-
1/18/2023 quarterly progress report was completed late on 5/5/2023.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022- Interim 2021.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
Adoption Closing Summary
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the
foster care worker and the Department of Health and
Services (DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of
service cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent
record.
Two of three finalized adoption records reviewed showed the child’s closing
summary (DHHS 222) was completed 9/14/2022 and 5/16/2023; more than 14 days
after the child’s respective 5/26/2022 and 1/10/2023 finalization date.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022
FOM 722-6B Family Team meeting.
9

FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers,
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.
Five of six open foster child records and two of two independent living records
reviewed did not show compliance:
Foster child records:
• One foster child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 12/2/2022-3/1/2023 USP.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
child’s 7/27/2022-11/4/2022 or 10/5/2022-1/26/2023 USP. An FTM
was completed on 8/24/2022 and 11/10/2022 which were not within
the aforementioned indicated respective timeframes, as required by
the rule.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
child’s 5/6/2022-8/3/2022 or 1/3/2023-4/30/2023 USP.
• Two other child records did not show consistent documentation of a
DHS-1105 for FTMs reported.
Independent living youth records:
• One youth’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the youth’s
1/23/2023- 4/22/2023 USP. The one completed on 2/3/2023 was too soon.
• A second youth’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
youth’s 2/12/2023-5/12/2023 USP.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
10

• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Four of six open foster child records and one of two independent living youth
records reviewed did not show compliance:
Foster child records:
• One foster child’s 9/3/2022-12/1/2023 and 12/2/2022-3/1/2022 treatment plan
did not show documentation of the birth parent’s or caregiver’s signature.
• A second foster child’s 2/23/2022-5/25/2022 treatment plan was not signed
by the birth mother until 8/2/2022. This child’s 5/24/2022-8/21/2022 treatment
and 11/19/2022- 2/17/2023 treatment plan did not show documentation of the
birth mother or caregiver’s signature.
• A third foster child’s 4/8/2022-7/6/2022 treatment plan did no show
documentation of the birthparent signature.
• A fourth foster child’s 8/4/2022-11/1/2022 treatment plan was not signed by
the birth mother until 1/26/2023; birth father until 4/20/2023 and caregiver
until 5/31/2023. This child’s 11/2/2022-1/10/2023 treatment plan was not
signed by the birth parents until 4/11/2023 and caregiver until 5/31/2023(all of
which the agency showed me at the Exit conference).
Independent living youth records:
• One youth’s 10/25/2022- 1/22/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
youth.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022; Interim 2021 Cite under FOM 722-8C.
FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show consistent updated
quarterly medical passports with dated medical information.
11

Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12209(1) Orientation and training
The agency was apprised that its proof of training shall clearly and consistently
show the employee's 16 hours of orientation and when each training hour(s) was
incurred. The total 16 hours shall not be illustrated as completed within one day.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12511(2) Termination
The agency is advised utilization of some type of receipt acknowledgment form
signed by the youth showing the items required by(a)-(d) of this rule were
provided the youth, may aid it in showing compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period. The first corrective action plan related to the agency's 2022
Renewal Inspection where the agency received the following rule and policy
violation:
• R400.12202 (1)(d) Policy and procedures.
• R400.12208(1) Job descriptions.
• R400,12212 (2)(b)-(d)Personnel records.
• R400.12212(2)(e)(i)(ii) Personnel records.
• R400.12212(2)(f)(h) Personnel records.
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12306 Application request.
• R400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
• R400.12324(8) Reevaluation.
• R400.12325(1) License recommendation.
12

• R400.12405(3)(f) Change of placement.
• R400.12405(5) (a)(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413 (1) (c)(ii) Medical and dental care policy.
• R400.12413(1)(f)(i) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2)(b) Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1)(h) Initial service plans.
• R400.12420 (1)(g) Updated service plans.
• R400.12505(1)(a) Supervision.
• R400.12605(1) Adoptive family evaluation.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• ISEP 6.19(5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment
69).
• ADM 300 Child adoption assessment addendum.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• Adm 710 State Ward Tracking System & Registration on Michigan Adoption
Resource Exchange.
• ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
• FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, and Timeframes.
• FOM 722-8 D Treatment plans- Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary- Completion
Requirements.
• FOM 801-3 Medical Passports.
• FOM 802-2 Mental and Behavioral Health.
As it relates to the agency’s efforts to achieve this corrective action plan, the
agency provided, documentations showing it completed trainings denoted in this
corrective action plan; samples of email reminders to staff on task due dates,
sample supervisor/worker meetings showing reviews and discussions of
medical/dental exams, medical passports, report statuses/due dates. The agency
made some progress with this corrective action plan, especially related to
personnel records and certification compliance. Notwithstanding this, the agency
had a number of non-compliances related to foster care, independent living and
adoption records. Many of these violations were repeat violations as indicated in
this inspection report.
The agency also experienced significant staff turnover again this licensing period.
This staffing issue impacted their compliance across the board. It is noteworthy
that all of the agency’s four foster care workers are new, as is one of its two
adoption workers, and its two-licensing worker. The agency hopes to hire another
foster worker soon, which would enable them to be better equipment with
completion of assignments, should a worker leave. They also now have two foster
care supervisor, one promoted internally and the other who was hired March of
this year. Additionally, to aid the agency in gaining staffing stability and greater
sustained performability, the agency’s foster care/adoption supervisor has been
13

promoted to program manager, and the licensing supervisor will be the licensing/
adoption supervisor.
The agency’s second corrective action plan related to special investigation
2023C000176 initiated 1/19/2023. The complaint related to an allegation of the
agency completing a safety plan for a youth which consisted of placing the youth
in an unlicensed, unrelated home for four plus days. The agency was found in
violation of R400.12404(1) for placement. The agency submitted an acceptable
corrective plan which was approved on 5/9/2023. The agency progress on this
corrective action plan cannot be determined at this time, because not enough time
has passed.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a copy of its chief administrator's report dated 4/10/2023;
and signed 5/15/2023. The agency completed the report as required.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of its annual budget and the most recent independent
financial audit report. No specific major areas of concern were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were basically positive. Areas reported as needing to improve
related to conducting more recruitment of foster families utilizing enhanced
technological advertisement; helping caregivers with any late payment issues and
becoming fully staffed.
One youth was interviewed. The youth reported favorable comments about the
agency, especially their case worker. Needed area of improvements reported by
the youth related to, workers being consistently timely for home visits, and new
workers perhaps working with a mentor to help them become knowledgeable of all
work tasks quicker, so as to perform them related to independent living youths.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency did not reveal any areas of concern.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety alerts:.
Safety Alert # 1
Concern:
No operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
The agency reported the foster parent installed the device in the kitchen and
provided a picture showing that installation on 4/6/2023. The agency provided a
14

copy of that photo.
Safety Alert # 2
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst scheduled a home visit with the relative for 4/3/2023.The
relative did not respond to the DCWL Analyst’s attempts to confirm the home visit.
The relative later reported to the DCWL Analyst via a text message that she would
not be participating with the home visit process. The DCWL Analyst advised the
agency of the relative’s refusal to cooperate, and of the agency’s need to verify the
safety of the home.
Resolution:
The agency attempted a home visit with the unlicensed relative on 4/7/2023 and the
relative refused the visit due to the Good Friday holiday. A safety plan was verbally
agreed to until a home visit could occur to the unlicensed relative’s home on
4/11/2023. On 4/11/2023 the agency completed a visit to the unlicensed relative’s
home. The home had an operable combination smoke/carbon monoxide detector
located in the kitchen. A photo was provided of the device. The 18-year old’s foster
youth’s bed room was observed with no reported concerns, a photo of the youth’s.
bedroom was provided. No weapons, firearms or ammunition were in the home.
There was a working cell phone; medications and cleaning supplies were
appropriately stored; there was operable running water, working utilities, toilets,
sinks, and the home has an ADT security system. A concern was noted related to
the home’s roof/ceiling. The relative reported some drywall and roof repair is
needed. The relative reported the two rooms are unoccupied/only used for
storage. The plan is to obtain a repair assessment by a company located across
from the relative’s home when the weather is warmer.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
June 14, 2023
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 15, 2023
________________________________________
Linda D Tansil Date
15
